data.questionHtml:
Compare the fractions:

(i) 58and712
(ii) 59and1115
(iii) 1112and1516
data.solutionHtml:
We have the following:

(i) 58 and 712
  
By cross multiplication, we get:
5 × 12 = 60 and 7 × 8 = 56
However, 60 > 56
∴  58>712

(ii) 59and1115
By cross multiplication, we get:
 5 × 15 = 75 and 9 × 11 = 99
However, 75 < 99
∴  59<1115

(iii) 1112and1516
By cross multiplication, we get:
11 × 16 = 176 and 12 × 15 = 180
However, 176 < 180
∴  1112<1516

data.questionHtml:
Arrange the following fractions in ascending order:

(i) 34,56,79,1112
(ii) 45,710,1115,1720
data.solutionHtml:
(i) The given fractions are 34,56,79and1112.
    
LCM of 4, 6, 9 and 12 = 36
    
Now, let us change each of the given fractions into an equivalent fraction with 72 as its denominator.
34=3×94×9=2736 

56=5×66×6=3036

79=7×49×4=2836

1112=11×312×3=3336

Clearly, 2736<2836<3036<3336

Hence,34<79<56<1112

∴ The given fractions in ascending order are 34, 79, 56 and 1112.

(ii) The given fractions are: 45, 710, 1115 and 1720.

LCM of 5, 10, 15 and 20 = 60

Now, let us change each of the given fractions into an equivalent fraction with 60 as its denominator.

45=4×125×12=4860

710=7×610×6=4260

1115=11×415×4=4460

1720=17×320×3=5160

Clearly, 4260<4460<4860<5160

Hence,710<1115<45<1720

∴ The given fractions in ascending order are 710, 1115, 45 and 1720.

data.questionHtml:
Arrange the following fractions in descending order:

(i) 34,78,712,1724
(ii) 23,35,710,815
data.solutionHtml:
We have the following:
(i) The given fractions are 34, 78, 712 and 1724.

LCM of 4,8,12 and 24 = 24

Now, let us change each of the given fractions into an equivalent fraction with 24 as its denominator.
34=3×64×6=1824

78=7×38×3=2124

712=7×212×2=1424

1724=17×124×1=1724

Clearly, 2124>1824>1724>1424

Hence, 78>34>1724>712

∴ The given fractions in descending order are 78, 34, 1724 and 712.

(ii) The given fractions are 23, 35, 710 and 815.
LCM of 3,5,10 and 15 = 30
Now, let us change each of the given fractions into an equivalent fraction with 30 as its denominator.
23=2×103×10=2030

35=3×65×6=1830

710=7×310×3=2130

815=8×215×2=1630

Clearly, 2130>2030>1830>1630

Hence, 710>23>35>815

∴ The given fractions in descending order are 710, 23, 35 and 815.

data.questionHtml: Reenu got <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math> part of an apple while Sonal got <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> part of it. Who got the larger part and by how much?
data.solutionHtml:
We will compare the given fractions 27and45 in order to know who got the larger part of the apple.
We have,
By cross multiplication, we get:
2 × 5 = 10  and 4 × 7 = 28

However, 10 < 28
∴ 27<45
Thus, Sonal got the larger part of the apple.

Now, 45-27=28-1035=1835

∴ Sonal got 1835 part of the apple more than Reenu.

data.questionHtml:
Find the sum:

(i) 59+39
(ii) 89+712
(iii) 56+78
(iv) 712+1116+924
(v) 345+2310+1115
(vi) 834+1025
data.solutionHtml:
(i) 59+39=89

(ii) 89+712
    
     = 3236 + 2136            [∵ LCM of 9 and 12 = 36]

      = 32+2136          
         
      = 5336=11736

(iii) 56+78

      = 2024 + 2124                   [∵ LCM of 6 and 8 = 24]

       = 20+2124

       =4124=11724

(iv) 712+1116+924

     2848 + 3348 + 1848             [∵ LCM of 12, 16 and 24 = 48]

      = 28+33+1848

      = 7948=13148

(v) 345+2310+1115

     = 195+2310+1615

   = 11430 + 6930 + 3230            [∵ LCM of 5, 10 and 15 = 30]

     = 114+69+3230

     = 21530=7530 = 716

(vi) 834+1025

      = 354+525

     = 17520 + 20820                  [∵ LCM of 4 and 5 = 20]

      = 175+20820

      = 38320=19320

data.questionHtml:
Find the difference:

(i) 57-27
(ii) 56-34
(iii) 315-710
(iv) 7-423
(v) 3310-1715
(vi) 259-1715
data.solutionHtml:
(i) 57-27=5-27=37

(ii) 56-34

     = 1012 - 912                 [∵ LCM of 6 and 4 = 12]

     = 10-912             
    
      = 112

(iii) 315-710

      = 165-710

     =  3210 - 710         [∵ LCM of 5 and 10 = 10]

      =  32-710
          
      = 2510=52=212

(iv) 7-423

       =  71-143

       = 21-143        [∵ LCM of 1 and 3 = 3]
          
       = 73=213

(v) 3310-1715

      = 3310-2215

      = 99-4430              [∵ LCM of 10 and 15 = 30]
      
      = 5530=116=156

(vi) 259-1715

       = 239-2215

       = 115-6645                [∵ LCM of 9 and 15 = 45]
 
       =4945=1445

data.questionHtml:
Simplify:

(i) 23+56-19
(ii) 8-412-214
(iii) 856-338+1712
data.solutionHtml:
(i) 23+56-19

   = 12+15-218    [∵ LCM of 3, 6 and 9 = 18]

  = 27-218=2518=1718

(ii) 8-412-214

 = 81-92-94

 = 32-18-94     [∵ LCM of 1, 2 and 4 = 4]

 = 32-274=54=114

(iii) 856-338+1712

    = 536-278+1912

    =212-81+3824     [∵ LCM of 6, 8 and 12 = 24]

    = 250-8124=16924=7124

data.questionHtml: Aneeta bought <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> kg apples and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> kg guava. What is the total weight of fruits purchased by her?
data.solutionHtml:
Total weight of fruits bought by Aneeta = 334 + 412 kg
Now, we have:

334 + 412 = 154 + 92

                =15 + 184     [∵ LCM of 2 and 4 = 4]

                =15 + 184=334=814

Hence, the total weight of the fruits purchased by Aneeta is 814 kg.

data.questionHtml: A rectangular sheet of paper is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>15</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> cm long and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>12</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> cm wide. Find its perimeter.
data.solutionHtml:
We have:

Perimeter of the rectangle ABCD = AB + BC + CD +DA
= 1534 + 1212 + 1534 + 1212 cm
= 634 + 252 + 634 + 252 cm
= 63 + 50 + 63 + 504 cm          [∵ LCM of 2 and 4 = 4]
= 2264 cm=1132 cm=5612 cm

Hence, the perimeter of ABCD is 5612 cm.

data.questionHtml: A picture is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>7</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> cm wide. How much should it be trimmed to fit in a frame <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>7</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>10</mn></mfrac></math> cm wide?
data.solutionHtml:
Actual width of the picture = 735cm=385cm
Required width of the picture = 7310cm=7310cm
∴ Extra width = 385-7310cm
                       = 76-7310cm       [∵ LCM of 5 and 10 is 10]
                       = 310cm
Hence, the width of the picture should be trimmed by 310 cm.

data.questionHtml: What should be added to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>7</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> to get 18?
data.solutionHtml:
Required number to be added = 18-735

                                                =181-385

                                                = 90-385             [∵ LCM of 1 and 5 = 5]
                                                = 525=1025

Hence, the required number is 1025.

data.questionHtml: What should be added to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>7</mn><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>15</mn></mfrac></math> to get <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>8</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math>?
data.solutionHtml:
Required number to be added = 825-7415

                                                = 425-10915

                                                = 126-10915    [∵ LCM of 5 and 15 = 15]
                                               
                                               =1715=1215

Hence, the required number should be 1215.

data.questionHtml: A piece of wire <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> m long broke into two pieces. One piece is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> m long. How long is the other piece?
data.solutionHtml:
Required length of other piece of wire = 334-112m

                                                  =154-32m

                                                  =15-64m    [∵ LCM of 4 and 2 = 4]

                                                  = 94m=214m

Hence, the length of the other piece of wire is 214m.

data.questionHtml: A film show lasted of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> hours. Out of this time <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> hours was spent on advertisements. What was the actual duration of the film?
data.solutionHtml:
Actual duration of the film = 323-112hours

                                           = 113-32hours

                                           = 22-96hours   [∵ LCM of 3 and 2 = 6]

                                           = 136hours=216hours

Hence, the actual duration of the film was 216hours.

data.questionHtml: Of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>9</mn></mfrac></math> , which is greater and by how much?
data.solutionHtml:
First we have to compare the fractions: 23 and 59.
By cross multiplication, we have:
2 × 9 = 18 and 5 × 3 = 15

However, 18 > 15
∴23>59

So, 23 is larger than 59.
Now, 23-59

      = 6-59    [∵ LCM of 3 and 9 = 9]
      =19
Hence, 23 is 19 part more than 59.

data.questionHtml: The cost of a pen is Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>16</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> and that of a pencil is Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>. Which costs more and by how much?
data.solutionHtml:
First, we have to compare the cost of the pen and the pencil.
Cost of the pen = Rs 1635 = Rs 835

Cost of the pencil = Rs 434 = Rs 194
Now, we have to compare fractions 835 and 194.
By cross multiplication, we get:

83 × 4 = 332 and 19 × 5 = 95

However, 332 > 95

∴ 835>194

So, the cost of pen is more than that of the pencil.
Now, Rs 835 - 194

      = Rs 332 - 9520     [∵ LCM of 4 and 5 = 20]

      = Rs 23720 = Rs 111720

∴ The pen costs Rs 111720 more than the pencil.

data.questionHtml:
Find the product:

(i) 35×711
(ii) 58×47
(iii) 49×1516
(iv) 25×15
(v) 815×20
(vi) 58×1000
(vii) 318×16
(viii) 2415×12
(ix) 367×423
(x) 912×1919
(xi) 418×21011
(xii) 556×157
data.solutionHtml:
(i) 35×711=3×75×11=2155

(ii) 58×47=5×48×7=5×12×7=514

(iii) 49×1516=4×159×16=1×53×4=512

(iv) 25×15=25×151=2×155×1=2×31×1=6

(v) 815×20=815×201=8×2015×1=8×43×1=323=1023

(vi) 58×1000=58×10001=5×10008×1=5×1251×1=625

(vii) 318×16=258×161=25×168×1=25×21×1=50

(viii) 2415×12=3415×121=34×1215×1=34×45×1=1365=2715

(ix) 367×423=277×143=27×147×3=9×21×1=18

(x) 912×1919=192×2819=19×282×19=1×141×1=14

(xi) 418×21011=338×3211=33×328×11=3×41×1=12

(xii) 556×157=356×127=35×126×7=5×21×1=10

data.questionHtml:
Simplify:

(i) 23×544×3335
(ii) 1225×1528×3536
(iii) 1027×2865×3956
(iv) 147×11322×1115
(v) 2217×729×13352
(vi) 3116×737×12539
data.solutionHtml:
We have the following:

(i) 23×544×3335=2×5×333×44×35=1×1×111×22×7=1×1×11×2×7=114

(ii)1225×1528×3536=1×3×55×4×3=1×1×11×4×1=14

(iii) 1027×2865×3956=10×1×327×5×2=1×1×327×1×1=327=19

(iv) 147×11322×1115

      =117×3522×1615=11×35×167×22×15=1×5×161×2×15=1×1×81×1×3=83=223

(v) 2217×729×13352

     =3617×659×8552=36×65×8517×9×52=4×5×51×1×4=1×5×51×1×1=25

(vi) 3116×737×12539

      =4916×527×6439=7×4×41×1×3=1123=3713

data.questionHtml:
Find:

(i) 13 of 24
(ii) 34 of 32
(iii) 59 of 45
(iv) 750 of 1000
(v) 320 of 1020
(vi) 511 of Rs 220
(vii) 49 of 54 metres
(viii) 67 of 35 litres
(ix) 16 of an hour
(x) 56  of an year
(xi) 720  of a kg
(xii) 920 of a metre
(xiii) 78 of a day
(xiv) 37 of a week
(xv) 750 of a litre
data.solutionHtml:
We have the following:

(i) 13 of 24 = 24×13=241×13=24×11×3=8

(ii) 34 of 32 = 32×34=321×34=32×31×4=8×31×1=24

(iii) 59 of 45 = 45×59=451×59=45×51×9=5×51×1=25

(iv) 750 of 1000 = 1000×750=10001×750=20×71×1=140

(v) 320 of 1020 = 1020×320=10201×320=51×31×1=153

(vi) 511 of Rs 220 = Rs 220×511 = Rs (20 × 5 ) = Rs 100

(vii) 49of 54 m = 49×54m = (4 × 6) m = 24 m

(viii) 67 of 35 L = 67×35L = (6 × 5) L = 30 L

(ix) 16 of 1 h = 16 of 60 min = 60×16 min = 10 min

(x) 56 of an year = 56 of 12 months = 12×56 months = (2 × 5) months = 10 months

(xi) 720 of a kg = 720 of 1000 g = 1000×720 g = (50 × 7) gm = 350 g

(xii) 920 of 1 m = 920 of 100 cm = 100×920 cm = (5 × 9) cm = 45 cm

(xiii) 78 of a day = 78 of 24 h = 24×78 h = (3 × 7) = 21 h

(xiv) 37 of a week = 37 of 7 days = 7×37 days = 3 days

(xv) 750 of 1 L = 750 of 1000 ml = 1000×750 ml = (20 × 7) ml = 140 ml

data.questionHtml: Apples are sold at Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>18</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> per kg. What is the cost of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> kg of apples?
data.solutionHtml:
Cost of 1kg of apples = Rs 1825= Rs 925
∴ Cost of 334 kg of apples = Rs 925 × 334
                                           = Rs 925 × 154 = Rs 23 × 31 × 1 = Rs 69

Hence, the cost of 334 kg of apples is Rs 69.

data.questionHtml: Cloth is being sold at Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>42</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> per metre. What is the cost of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> metres of this cloth?
data.solutionHtml:
Cost of 1 m of cloth = Rs 4212 = Rs 852
∴ Cost of 535 m of cloth = Rs 852×535
                                        = Rs 852×285=Rs 85×282×5=Rs 17×14=Rs 238
Hence, the cost of 535m of cloth is Rs 238.

data.questionHtml: A car covers a certain distance at a uniform speed of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>66</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> km per hour. How much distance will it cover in 9 hours?
data.solutionHtml:
Distance covered by the car in 1 h = 6623 km
Distance covered by the car in 9 h  =6623×9 km
                                                            =2003×9 km=200×93×1 km=200×3 km=600 km

Hence, the distance covered by the car in 9 h will be 600 km.

data.questionHtml: One tin holds <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>12</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> litres of oil. How many litres of oil can 26 such tins hold?
data.solutionHtml:
Capacity of 1 tin = 1234 L=514 L
∴ Capacity of 26 such tins =26×514 L
                                           =261×514 L=26×511×4 L=13×511×2 L=6632 L=33112 L

Hence, 26 such tins can hold 33112 L of oil.

data.questionHtml: For a particular show in a circus, each ticket costs Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>35</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. If 308 tickets are sold for the  show, how much amount has been collected?
data.solutionHtml:
Cost of 1 ticket = Rs 3512= Rs 712
∴ Cost of 308 tickets = Rs 712×308=Rs 712×3081=Rs (71×154)=Rs 10934

Hence, 308 tickets were sold for Rs 10,934.

data.questionHtml: Nine boards are stacked on the top of each other. The thickness of each board is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> cm. How high is the stack?
data.solutionHtml:
Thickness of 1 board = 323 cm
∴ Thickness of 9 boards = 9×323 cm
                                        =91×113 cm = (3 × 11) cm = 33 cm

Hence, the height of the stack is 33 cm.

data.questionHtml: Rohit takes <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> minutes to make complete round of a circular park. How much time will he take to make 15 rounds?
data.solutionHtml:
Time taken by Rohit to complete one round of the circular park = 445 min = 245min

∴ Time taken to complete 15 rounds =15×245 min
                                                                      = (3 × 24) min
                                                                      = 72 min
                                                                      = 1 h 12 min   [∵ 1 hr = 60 min]

Hence, Rohit will take 1 h 12 min to make 15 complete rounds of the circular park.

data.questionHtml: Amit weighs 35 kg. His sister Kavita's weight is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> of Amit's weight. How much does Kavita weigh?
data.solutionHtml:
Weight of Amit = 35 kg
Weight of Kavita = 35 of Amit's weight
                             = 35 kg x 35 = 35×35kg=(7×3) kg=21 kg
Hence, Kavita's weight is 21 kg.

data.questionHtml: There are 42 students in a class and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>7</mn></mfrac></math> of the students are boys. How many girls are there in the class?
data.solutionHtml:
Number of boys in the class = 57 of the total no. of students
                                           =57 × 42 = 5×427=5×6=30

∴ Number of girls in the class = 42 − 30 = 12

Hence, there are 12 girls in the class.

data.questionHtml: Sapna earns Rs 12000 per month. She spends <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac></math> of her income and deposits rest of the money in a bank. How much money does she deposit in the bank each month?
data.solutionHtml:
Sapna's total monthly income = Rs 12000
Monthly expenditure = 78 of Rs 12000
                                   = Rs 78×12000=Rs (7 × 1500) = Rs 10500
∴ Monthly savings = Rs 12000 − Rs 10500
                                = Rs 1500

Hence, Sapna deposits Rs 1500 in the bank every month.

data.questionHtml: Each side of a square field is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> m. Find its area.
data.solutionHtml:
Side of the square field = 423 m
∴ Area of the square = (side)2
                                  = 423 m2
                                  = 143 m2=143 m ×143 m=14×143×3 m2=1969 m2=2179 m2

Hence, the area of the square field is 2179 m2.

data.questionHtml: Find the area of a rectangular park which is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>41</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> m long and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>18</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> m broad.
data.solutionHtml:
Length of the rectangular park = 4123 m=1253 m

Its breadth = 1835 m=935 m

∴ Its area = length × breadth

               = 1253×935 m2
                = (25 × 31) m = 775 m2

Hence, the area of the rectangular park is 775 m2.

data.questionHtml:
Write down the reciprocal of:

(i) 58
(ii) 7
(iii) 112
(iv) 1235
data.solutionHtml:
(i) Reciprocal of 58 = 85            [ ∵ 58×85=1]

(ii) Reciprocal of  7 =17             [ ∵ 7×17=1]

(iii) Reciprocal of  112 = 12       [ ∵ 112×12=1]

(iv) Reciprocal of 1235 = Reciprocal of 635 =563            [∵ 635×563=1]

data.questionHtml:
Simplify:

(i)  47÷914
(ii) 710÷35
(iii) 89÷16
(iv) 9÷13
(v) 24÷67
(vi) 335÷45
(vii) 337÷821
(viii) 547÷1310
(ix) 1537÷12349
data.solutionHtml:
(i) 47÷914=47×149              [∵ Reciprocal of 914 = 149]

    = 89

(ii) 710÷35=710×53            [∵ Reciprocal of 35 = 53]

     = 76=116

(iii) 89÷16=89×116              [∵ Reciprocal of 16 = 116]

       = 118

(iv) 9÷13=9×3                      [∵ Reciprocal of 13 = 3]

     = 27


(v) 24÷67=24×76                [∵ Reciprocal of 67 = 76]

    = 4 × 7 = 28


(vi) 335÷45=185÷45

     = 185×54            [∵ Reciprocal of 45 = 54]

      = 184=92=412

(vii) 337÷821=247÷821

       = 247×218          [∵ Reciprocal of 821 = 218]

       = 3  3 = 9


(viii) 547÷1310 =397÷1310

       = 397×1013             [∵ Reciprocal of 1310 = 1013]

       = 307=427


(ix) 1537÷12349 = 1087÷7249

      = 1087×4972          [∵ Reciprocal of 7249 = 4972]

      = 9×71×6=3×71×2=212=1012

data.questionHtml:
Divide:

(i) 1124 by 78
(ii) 678 by 1116
(iii) 559 by 313
(iv) 32 by 135
(v) 45 by 145
(vi) 63 by 214
data.solutionHtml:
(i)  1124÷78

      = 1124×87                           [∵ Reciprocal of 78 = 87]

      = 1121

(ii) 678÷1116 = 558÷1116

       =558×1611         [∵ Reciprocal of 1116 = 1611]

       = 5 × 2 = 10

(iii) 559÷313 = 509÷103

        = 509×310          [∵ Reciprocal of 103 = 310]

        =  53 = 123

(iv) 32÷135 = 32÷85

      = 32×58                [∵ Reciprocal of 85 = 58]

      = 4 × 5 = 20

(v) 45÷145 = 45÷95

      = 45×59               [∵ Reciprocal of 95 = 59]

      = 5 × 5 = 25

(vi) 63÷214 = 63÷94

      = 63×49            [∵ Reciprocal of 94 = 49]

      = 7 × 4 = 28

data.questionHtml: A rope of length <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>13</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> m has been divided into 9 pieces of the same length. What is the length of each piece?
data.solutionHtml:
Length of the rope = 1312 m =272 m
Number of equal pieces = 9

∴ Length of each piece = 272÷9 m
                                      = 272×19 m      [∵ Reciprocal of 9 = 19]
                                      = 32 m =112 m
Hence, the length of each piece of rope is 112 m.

data.questionHtml: 18 boxes of nails weigh equally and their total weight is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>49</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> kg. How much does each box weigh?
data.solutionHtml:
Weight of 18 boxes of nails = 4912 kg = 992 kg
∴ Weight of 1 box = 992÷18 kg
                            = 992×118 kg         [∵ Reciprocal of 18 = 118]
                            = 99×12×18 kg = 11×12×2 kg =114 kg = 234 kg

Hence, the weight of each box is 234 kg.

data.questionHtml: By selling oranges at the rate of Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>3</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> per orange, a man gets Rs 210. How many oranges does he sell?
data.solutionHtml:
Cost of 1 orange = Rs 334 = Rs 154
Total cost of the oranges sold by the man = Rs 210

∴ Required number of oranges = 210÷154
                                                = 210×415      [∵ Reciprocal of 154 = 415]
                                                = (14 × 4) = 56

Hence, the man sold 56 oranges.

data.questionHtml: Mangoes are sold at Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>18</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> per kg. What is the weight of mangoes available for Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>157</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> ?
data.solutionHtml:
Cost of 1 kg of mangoes = Rs 1812= Rs372
Total cost of the required mangoes = Rs 15714 = Rs 6294
∴ Weight of the required mangoes = 6294÷372 kg
                                                   =6294×237 kg      [∵ Reciprocal of 372 = 237]
                                                   = 172 kg = 812 kg
Hence, the weight of the mangoes available for Rs 15714 is 812 kg.

data.questionHtml: Vikas can cover a distance of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>20</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> km in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>7</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> hours on foot. How many km per hour does he walk?
data.solutionHtml:
Distance covered by Vikas in 734 h = 2023 km
∴ Distance covered by him in 1 h = 2023÷734 km
                                                   = 623÷314 km
                                                   = 623×431 km
                                                    = 2×43 km =83 km = 223 km

Hence, the distance covered by Vikas in 1 h is 223 km.

data.questionHtml: Preeti bought <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>8</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math> kg of sugar for Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>148</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>. Find the price of sugar per kg.
data.solutionHtml:
Cost of 812 kg of sugar = Rs 14834
∴ Cost of 1 kg of sugar = Rs 14834÷812
                                    = Rs 5954÷172
                                    = Rs 5954×217 = Rs 352 = Rs 1712

Hence, the cost of 1 kg of sugar is Rs 1712.

data.questionHtml: If the cost of a notebook is Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>7</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>, how many notebooks can be purchased for Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>69</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> ?
data.solutionHtml:
Cost of 1 notebook = Rs 734  = Rs 314
∴ Number of notebooks purchased for Rs 6934 = 6934÷314
                                                                        =2794÷314
                                                                        =2794×431    [∵ Reciprocal of 314 =413]
                                                                        =27931 = 9
Hence, 9 notebooks can be purchased for Rs 6934.

data.questionHtml: At a charity show the price of each ticket was Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>10</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. The total amount collected by a boy was Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>283</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. How many tickets were sold by him?
data.solutionHtml:
Cost of 1 ticket = Rs 1012 = Rs 212
Total amount collected by the boy = Rs 28312 = Rs 5672
∴ Number of tickets sold = 5672÷212

                                         = 5672×221     [∵ Reciprocal of 212 = 221]

                                         = 56721=27

Hence, the boy sold 27 tickets of the charity show.

data.questionHtml: A group of students arranged a picnic. Each student contributed Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>61</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. The total contribution was Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>676</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. How many students are there in the group?
data.solutionHtml:
Amount contributed by 1 student = Rs 6112 = Rs 1232
Total amount collected = Rs 67612 = Rs 13532
∴ Number of students in the group = 13532÷1232

                                                      = 13532×2123        [∵ Reciprocal of 1232 = 2123]

                                                      =1353123=11

Hence, there are 11 students in the group.

data.questionHtml: 24 litres of milk was distributed equally among all the students of a hostel. If each student got <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> litre of milk, how many students are there in the hostel?
data.solutionHtml:
Quantity of milk given to each student  = 25 L
Total quantity of milk distributed among all the students = 24 L

∴ Number of students = 24÷25

                                    = 24×52       [∵ Reciprocal of 25 = 52]

                                    = (12 × 5) = 60

Hence, there are 60 students in the hostel.

data.questionHtml: A bucket contains <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>20</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> litres of water. A small jug has a capacity of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> litre. How many times the jug has to be filled with water from the bucket to get it emptied?
data.solutionHtml:
Capacity of the small jug = 34 L
Capacity of the bucket = 2014 L = 814 L
∴ Required number of small jugs = 814 ÷ 34
                                                   = 814×43      [∵ Reciprocal of 34 = 43]
                                                   = 813 = 27

Hence, the small jug has to be filled 27 times to empty the water from the bucket.

data.questionHtml: The product of two numbers is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>15</mn><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac></math>. If one of the numbers is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>, find the other.
data.solutionHtml:
Product of the two numbers = 1556 =956

One of the numbers = 613 =193

∴ The other number = 956 ÷ 193

                                 = 956 × 319     [∵ Reciprocal of 193 = 319]

                               = 52 = 212

Hence, the other number is 212.

data.questionHtml: By what number should <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>9</mn><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> be multiplied to get 42?
data.solutionHtml:
Product of the two numbers = 42
One of the numbers = 945 = 495
∴ The other number = 42 ÷ 495
                                 =42 × 549           [∵ Reciprocal of 495 = 549]
                                 =6 × 57 = 307 = 427

Hence, the required number is 427.

data.questionHtml: By what number should <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>9</mn></mfrac></math> be divided to obtain <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>?
data.solutionHtml:
Required number = 629 ÷ 423
                            = 569 ÷ 143
                            = 569  × 314     [ ∵ Reciprocal of 143 = 314]
                            = 43=113

Hence, we have to divide 629 by 113 to get 423.

data.questionHtml:
Mark (✓) against the correct answer
Which of the following is a vulgar fraction?

(a) 310
(b) 1310
(c) 103
(d) none of these
data.solutionHtml:
(c) 103

103 is a vulgar fraction, because its denominator is other than 10, 100, 1000, etc.

data.questionHtml:
Mark (✓) against the correct answer
Which of the following is an improper fraction?

(a) 710
(b) 79
(c) 97
(d) none of these
data.solutionHtml:
(c) 97
97 is an improper fraction, because its numerator is greater than its denominator.

data.questionHtml:
Mark (✓) against the correct answer
Which of the following is a reducible fraction?

(a) 105112
(b) 104121
(c) 7772
(d) 4663
data.solutionHtml:
(a) 105112

A fraction that is reducible can be reduced by dividing both the numerator and denominator by a common factor.

105÷7112÷7=1516

Thus, 105112 is a reducible fraction.

data.questionHtml:
Mark (✓) against the correct answer
23,46,69,812 are
(a) like fractions
(b) irreducible fractions
(c) equivalent fractions
(d) none of these
data.solutionHtml:
(c) equivalent fractions

Equivalent fractions are those which are the same but look different.

Thus, 23, 46=23, 69=23, 812=23 are equivalent fractions.

data.questionHtml:
Mark (✓) against the correct answer
Which of the following statements is true?

(a) 916=1324
(b) 916<1324
(c) 916>1324
(d) none of these
data.solutionHtml:
(c) 916 > 1324
The two fraction are 916 and 1324.
By cross multiplication, we have:
9 × 24 = 216 and 13 × 16 = 208
However, 216 > 208
∴ 916 > 1324

data.questionHtml:
Mark (✓) against the correct answer
Which one of the following is the correct statement?

(a) 23<35<1415
(b) 35<23<1415
(c) 1415<35<23
(d) none of these
data.solutionHtml:
(b) 35<23<1415

The given fractions are 35, 23 and1415.

LCM of 5, 3 and 15 = 15

Now, we have:

23×55=1015, 35×33=915 and 1415×11=1415

Clearly, 915 <1015<1415

∴ 35<23<1415

data.questionHtml:
Mark (✓) against the correct answer
A car runs 16 km using 1 litre of petrol. How much distance will it cover in 234 litres of petrol?
(a) 24 km
(b) 36 km
(c) 44 km
(d) 3234 km
data.solutionHtml:
(c) 44 km
Distance covered by the car on 234 L of petrol =16×234 km

                                                                   = 16×114 km

                                                                   = (4 × 11) km = 44 km

data.questionHtml:
Mark (✓) against the correct answer
Lalit reads a book for 134 hours evrey day and reads the entire book in 6 days. How many hours does he take to read the entire book?

(a) 1012 hours
(b) 912 hours
(c) 712 hours
(d) 1112 hours
data.solutionHtml:
(a) 1012 hours
Time taken by Lalit to read the entire book = 6×134 h

                                                                   = 6×74 h

                                                                     = 212 h = 1012 h

data.questionHtml:
Define:

(i) Fractions
(ii) Vulgar fractions
(iii) Improper fractions

Give two examples of each.
data.solutionHtml:
(i) A number of the form ab, where a and b are natural numbers, is called a natural number.
Here, a is the numerator and b is the denominator.

23 is a fraction with 2 as the numerator and 3 as the denominator.

125 is a fraction with 12 as the numerator and 5 as the denominator.

(ii) A fraction whose denominator is a whole number other than 10, 100, 1000, etc., is called a vulgar faction.
Examples: 25 and 415

(iii) A fraction whose numerator is greater than or equal to its denominator is called an improper fraction.
Examples: 113 and 4135

data.questionHtml: What should be added to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> to get 15?
data.solutionHtml:
Required number to be added = 15-635

                                             = 151-335

                                              = 75-335  [∵ LCM of 1 and 5 = 5]

                                              = 425=825

Hence, the required number is 825.

data.questionHtml: Simplify: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>9</mn><mfrac><mn>5</mn><mn>6</mn></mfrac><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mfrac><mn>7</mn><mn>12</mn></mfrac><mo>.</mo></math>
data.solutionHtml:
We have,

956-438+2712

= 596-358+3112

= 236-105+6224   [∵ LCM of 6, 8 and 12 = 24]

= 298-10524= 19324=8124

data.questionHtml:
Find:

(i) 1225 of a litre
(ii) 58 of a kilogram
(iii) 35 of an hour
data.solutionHtml:
We have:

(i) 1225 of 1 L = 1225 of 1000 ml = 1000×1225 ml = (40 × 12) ml = 480 ml

(ii)58 of 1 kg = 58 of 1000 g = 1000×58 g = (125 ×5) g = 625 g

(iii) 35 of 1 h = 35 of 60 min = 60×35 min = (12 × 3) min = 36 min

data.questionHtml: Milk is sold at Rs <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>37</mn><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> per litre. Find the cost of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> litres milk.
data.solutionHtml:
Cost of 1 L of milk = Rs 3734 =  Rs 1514
Cost of 625 L of milk = Rs 1514×625
                                 = Rs 1514×325
                                 = Rs 151×81×5 =  Rs 12085 = Rs 24135
Hence, the cost of 625 L of milk is Rs 24135.

data.questionHtml: The cost of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> kg of mangoes is Rs 189. At what rate per kg are the mangoes being sold?
data.solutionHtml:
Cost of  514 kg of mangoes = Rs 189
Cost of 1 kg of mango = Rs 189÷514
                                   = Rs 189÷214 
                                   = Rs 189×421      [∵ Reciprocal of 214 = 421]
                                   = Rs (9 × 4) = Rs 36

Hence, the mangoes are being sold at Rs 36 per kg.

data.questionHtml:

data.solutionHtml:

(i)134×225×347

     = 74×125×257

(ii) 559÷313

data.questionHtml: By what number should <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>6</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>9</mn></mfrac></math> be divided to obtain <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>?
data.solutionHtml:
Required number = 629÷423

                            = 569÷143

                            = 569×314    [∵ Reciprocal of 143 = 314]

                            = 43 = 113

Hence, we have to divide 629 by 113 to obtain 423.

data.questionHtml: Each side of a square is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> m long. Find its area.
data.solutionHtml:
Side of the square = 523 m = 173 m

Its area = (side)2 = 173m2 = 173m×173m=2899m2=3219 m2

Hence, the area of the square is 3219m2.

data.questionHtml:
Mark (✓) against the correct answer
Which of the following is an irreducible fraction?

(a) 105112
(b) 6677
(c) 4663
(d) 5185
data.solutionHtml:
(c) 4663

A fraction ab is said to be irreducible or in its lowest terms if the HCF of a and b is 1.
46 = 2 × 23 ×1
63 = 3 × 3× 21 ×1

Clearly, the HCF of 46 and 63 is 1.

Hence, 4663 is an irreducible fraction.

data.questionHtml:
Fill in the blanks.

(i) Reciprocal of 825 is ...... .
(ii) 1312÷8=......
(iii) 6934÷734=......
(iv) 4123×1835=......
(v) 8498(in irreducible form)= ......
data.solutionHtml:
(i) The reciprocal of 825 is 542.

Reciprocal of 825 = Reciprocal of 425 = 542

(ii) 1312÷8=11116

     1312÷8=272×18=2716=11116

(iii) 6934÷734=9

6934÷734=2794÷314

 =2794×431=27931 = 9

(iv) 4123÷1835=775

        4123×1835=1253×935
      
       = 1253×935=25×311×1=775

(v) 8498(irreducible form) = 67
  
The HCF of 84 and 98 is 14.
      
∴ 84÷1498÷14=67

data.questionHtml:
Write 'T' for true and 'F' for false

(i) 916<1324.
(ii) Among 25,1635 and 914, the largest is 1635.
(iii) 1115-920=1760.
(iv) 1125 of a litre = 440 mL.
(v) 1634×625=107310.
data.solutionHtml:
(i) F

     By cross multiplication, we have:

     9 × 24 = 216 and 13 × 16 = 208

     However, 216 > 208

     ∴ 916>1324

(ii) F

      The LCM of 5, 35 and 14 is 70.

      Now, 25=25×1414=2870; 1635=1635×22=3270 and 914=914×55=4570

      Clearly, 2870<3270<4570

      ∴ 25<1635<914

(iii) T

       The LCM of 15 and 20 = (5 × 3 × 4) = 60

        ∴ 1115-920=44-2760=1760
(iv) T

       1125 of 1 L = 1125 of 1000 ml = 1000×1125 ml = (40 × 11) ml = 440 ml

(v) F

      1634×625= 674×325=67×324×5=67×85=5365=10715
